div.p: THE Excellent Comedy, called THE OLD LAW: OR A new way to please you. Py Phil. Massinger. Tho. Middleton. William R●wley.

Acted before the King and Queene at Salisbury House, and at severall other places, with great Applause. Together with an exact and perfect Catalogue of all the Playes, with the Authors Names, and what are Comedies, Tragedies, Histories, Pastoralls, Masks, Interludes, more exactly Printed then ever before.
LONDON, Printed for Edward Archer, at the signe of the Adam and Eve, in Little Britaine. 1656.

list.item: Creon, Father to Simonides and Cleanthes.
Lisander Husband to Eugenia and Uncle to Cleanthes.
Antigona, Mother to Simonides and Cleanthes.
Eugenia, Wife to Lisander and Mother to Parthenia.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: IS the Law firm Sir?

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: The Law, what more firm Sir,
More powerfull, forcible, or more permanent?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: By my troth Sir,
I partly doe b●leeve it; conceive Sir
Y●u have indirectly answered my question.
I did not doubt the fundamentall grounds
Of Law in generall, for the most solid,
But this particular Law that me concerns
Now at the present, if that be firm and strong,
And powe●full, and forcible, and permanent.
I am ● yong man that has an old father.

sp.speaker: 2 Law.
sp.l: Nothing more strong Sir,
It is Secundum statutum Principis
Et voce republicae, nay consummatum
Et exemplificatum, is it not in force
When divers have already tasted it
And payd their lives for penalty?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Tis true.
My father must be next, this day compleats
Full fourscore years upon him.

sp.speaker: 2. Law.
sp.l: Hees heer then
Sub poena statuti, hence I can tell him.
T●uer then all the Physitians in the world,
He cannot live out to morrow; this is
The most certain Climactericall year,
Tis past all danger, for ther's no scaping it:
What age is your mother Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Faith neer her dayes to,
Wants some two of thre●score.

sp.speaker: 1. Law
sp.l: So, sh●el drop away
One of th●se day●s to; hee●s a good age now
For those that h●ve old p●rents, and rich inheritance.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And Sir tis profitable for others too:
Are there not fellows tha● lie bed-rid in their offices
That yonger men would wa●k lustily in:
Churchmen, ●hat ev●n ●he s●cond infancy
Hath silenc'd, yet hath spun out their lives so long
That many pregnant and ingenious spirits
Have langu●shd in their hop'd r●versio●s,
A●d died upon the thought, and by your leave Sir,
Have you not pl●ces fild up in th● L●w
By some grave Senators, that you imagin
Have held them long enough, and such sp●r●ts as you.
Were they remov'd, w●u●d leap into the●● d●gniti●●?

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Dic q● bus in terris & eri● mihi magnus Apollo.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Bu● tell me faith y●u f●ir opinion:
Ist not a sound and n●cessa●y Law
This (by the Duke) enact●d ●

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Nev●● d●d Gr●●ce
(Our 〈…〉 of brav● P●il●sophers)
Mongst all her N●m● the●●●nd Lawgiv●rs,
No● when she flou●ish●d in her seven fold sages,
(Whose living m●mory can ●●v●r die)
Produce a Law more grave and necessary.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'me of that mind to.

sp.speaker: 2●Law
sp.l: I w●ll maintain Sir,
Draco's Oliga●chy● that the gouernment
Of Comm●nity reduced into few
Fram'd a fair state; Solons Crecopedi
That cut off poor mens debts to their rich creditors
Was good and charitable (but not full allowd.)
His Sisaith●e did refo●m that error,
His honourable Senate of Are●pagitae,
Licurgus was more loose, and gave too free
And licentious reyns unto his discipline,
As that a yong woman in her husbands weaknes
Might choose her able friend to propogate;
That so the Commonwealth might be supplide,
With hope of lusty spirits, Plato did erre,
And so did Aristotle, allowing
Lewd and lu●u●ious limits to their Lawes;
But now our Epir●, our Epires Evander,
Our noble and wi●e Princ● has hit the Law
That all our predecessive students

Have mist unto their shame.
Enter Cleanthes,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Forbear the praise Sir.
Tis in it selfe most pleasing, Cleanthes
Oh lad heers a spring for yong plants to flourish,
The old trees must down kept the sun from us,
We shall rise now boy.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Whether Sir I pray?
To the ble●k air of storms, among those trees,
Which w● had shelter from.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yes from our growth,
Our sap and livelyhood and from our fruit,
W●●t tis not Jubilee with thee yet, I think,
Thou lookst so sad o●t, how old's thy father?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Jubilee, no indeed, tis a bad year with me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Prithee how old's thy father, then I can tell thee?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I know not how to answer you Simonides,
Hees is too old being now expos'd
Unto the rigor of a cruell Edict,
And yet not old enough by many years,
Cause I'de not see him goe an howr before me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: These ve●● p●ssions I speak to my father,
Come, come, heers none but friends heer, we may speak
Our insides freely, these are Lawyers man,
And shalbe Counsellors shortly.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: They shalbe now Sir,
And sh●ll have la●ge fees if thei'le undertake
To help a good cause (for it wants assistance)
Bad ones (I know) they can insist upon.

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Oh Sir. we must undertake of both parts,
But the good we have most good in.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Pray you say,
How doe you allow of this strange Edict?

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Secundum Iustitiam, by my faith Sir,
The happiest Edict that ever was in Epire.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What● to kill innocents Sir, it cannot be,
It is no rule in justice there to punish.

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Oh Sir,
You unde●stand a conscience, but not law.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Why sir, is there so main a differenc●?

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: You'l never be good Law●er if you und●rstand not that.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I think then tis the b●st to be a bad one.

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Why sir, the very letter and the sense both
Doe both orethrow you in this statute,
Which that speaks, that every man living to
Fourscore years, and women to threescore, shall then
Be cut off as fruitless to the Republike,
And Law shall finish what nature lingerd at.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And this suit shall soon be dispatcht in Law.

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: It is so plain it can have no Demur,
The Church-Booke overthrows it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And so it does
The Church Book overthrowes it if you read it well.

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Still you runne from the Law into error:
You say it takes the lives of Innocents,
I say no, and so sayes common reason:
What man lives to fourescore and women to three
That can die innocent?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: A fine lawfull evasion:
Good sir rehearse the full statute to me●

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Fie thats too tedious, you have already
The full sum in the breef relation.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, mongst many words may be found contradictions,
And these men dare sue and wrangle with a Statute,
If they can pick a quarrell with some error:

sp.speaker: 2. Law.
sp.p: Listen sir, ile gather it as breefe as I can for you, Anno Primo Evandri, bee it (for the care and good of the Com|mon wealth for divers necessary reasons that wee shall urge) thus peremptorily enacted●

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A faire pretence if the reasons foule it not.

sp.speaker: 2. Law.
sp.p: That all men living in our Dominions of Epire in their decayd nature, to the age of foure score, or women to the age of three score, shall on the same day bee instantly put to death, by those meanes and instruments that a former Proclamation had (to this purpose) through our said territories dispersed.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: There was no women in this Senate certain.

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.p: That these men being past their bearing Armes, to aide and defend their Countrey, past their manhood and livelihood, to propogate any further issue to their posterity, and as well past their councells (which overgrown gravity is now run into dotage) to assist their Countrey, to whom in common reason, nothing should be so wearisome as their owne lives, as it may be supposed is tedious to their successive heires, whose times are spent in the good of their Countrey, yet wanting the meanes to maintaine it; and are like to grow old before their inheritance (borne to them) come to their necessary use, for the which are the women, for that they never were defence to their Countrey, never by Counsell ad|mitted to the assist of government of their Countrey, onely neces|sary to the propagation of posterity, and now at the age of three|score to be past that good, and all their goodnesse: it is thought f●t then a quarter abated from the more worthy member to be put to death as is before recited: provided that for the just and impartiall execution of this our Statute the exa●ple shall first begin in and a|bout our Court, which our selfe will see carefully performed, and not for a full Month following extend any further into our Do|minions: Dated the sixt of the second month at our Pallace●Roy|all in Epire.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: A fine edict, and very fairely guilded
And is there no scruple in all these words,
To demurr the Law upon occasion?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Pox tis an unnecessary inquisition,
Prithee set him not about it.

sp.speaker: 2. Law.
sp.l: Troth none sir,
It is so evident and plain a case
There is no succor for the Defendant.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Possible, can nothing help in a good case?

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Faith sir I doe think there may be a hole
Which would protract delay if not remedie.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Why theres some comfort in that good sir? speake it●

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Nay you must pardon me for that sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Prithee doe not,
It may ope a wound to many Sonns and Heires
That may die after it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Come sir, I know how to make you speake, will this doo●?

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: I will afford you my opinion sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Pray you repeat the literall words expresly
The time of Death.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Tis an unnecessary question, prithee let it alone.

sp.speaker: 2. Law.
sp.l: Heare his opinion, twill be fruitlesse sir.
That man at the age of four ●core, and women at threescore
Sh●ll the same day be pu● to death.

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Thus I helpe the man to twenty one yeares more,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: That were a faire addition.

sp.speaker: 1. Law
sp.l: Mark it, sir wee s●y man is not at age
Till he be one and twenty before his infancy
And adole●censie, nor by that addition,
Fou●score he cannot be till a hundred and one.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Oh poore evasion!
Hees fourescore yeares old sir,

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: That help● more sir
He begins to be old at fifty, so at fourscore,
Hees but thirty yeares old, so believe it sir,
He may be twenty yeares in declination
And so long may a man linger and live bit

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: The worst hope of safety that ere I heard,
G●v● h●m his fee againe, tis not worth two de●eers.

sp.speaker: 1. Law
sp.l:
T●eres no L●w for rest●●u●ion of ●ees sir.
Enter Creon & Antigona.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.l: N● no sir, I meant it lost when twas given.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: No more good sir
Heere are eares unnecessary for your doctrine.

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: I have spo●● out my fee and I have done sir.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: Oh my deare father!

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: Tush meet me not in exclaimes
I understand the worst and hope no better:
A fine L●w, if this hold, white heads will be cheape
And many watch mens places will be vacant
Forty of em I know my seniors,
That did due deeds of darknesse to their Countrey,
H●s watchd em a good turne fort, and tane em
N●pping now, the fewer Hospitalls will serve to,
Many may be usd for stewes and brothells
And those people will never trouble em to fourescore.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: Can you play and sport with sorrow sir?

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: Sorrow, for what Antigona? for my life,
My sorrowes I have kept it so long well
With bringing it up unto so ill an end:
I might have gently lost it in my Cradle,
Before my Nerves and Ligaments grew strong
To ●inde it faster to me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: For mine owne sake
I should have be●ne sorry ●or that.

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: In my ●outh
I was a Son d●●r● no Coward in my age,
I never ●u●nd my back upon my foe,
I ●av● felt n●tu●●s win●●●s sickn●sses,
Y●t ●v●r k●pt a ●iv●ly s●p in me
To greet the ch●er●ful● sp●ing of health agen:
D●ngers on Ho●s●back, on Foot by W●ter,
I have scapd to this day, and yet this day
Without all help of casuall acc●dents
Is onely deadly to me, c●●se it numbers
Fou●score yeares to me, wher●s the ●au●t now?
I cannot blame Time, Natu●e, nor my Stars
Nor ought but Tyranny, ev●n Kings thems●lv●s
Have some times tasted an even f●te with me,
He that has beene a Souldier all his day●s
And stood in pe●sonall opposition, gainst D●rts and Arrowes, the Extreames o● heat,
And pinch●ng cold● has treacherously at home
In his secur●d quiet by a vi●lain●s hand
Am basely lost in my star●s ignorance
And so must I die by a Tyrants sword.

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Oh say not ●o sir, it is by the Law!

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: And whats that sir ●ut the sword of ●yranny
When it is brandish'd against inno●ent lives?
I'me now upon my death bed sir, and tis ●i●
I should unbosome my free conscience
And shew the faith I die in, I doe beleeve
Tis tyranny that ta●●es my life.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Would it were gone
By one means or other, what a long day
Will this be ere night?

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: Heer sit — w●eping.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Wherfore dost ●hou 〈◊〉?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Cause you make no more haste to your end.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: How can you qu●stion nature so unjustly?
I had a grandfather, and then had not you
True fili●ll tears for him?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Hypocrite●
A disease of drought dry up all pity from him
That c●n diss●mble pity with w●t eyes

sp.speaker: Cre
sp.l: Be good unto your mother Simonides,
She must be now your care.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: To what end sir?
The bell of this sharp edict towls for me
As it rings out for you, Ile be as ready
With one hours stay to goe along with you.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Thou must not wom●n, there are years behind
Before thou canst set forward in this voyage,
And nature sure will now, be kind to all:
She has a quarrell int, a cruell Law
Seeks to prevent her, sheel therfore fight int
And draw out life even to her longest thred
Thou art scarce fifty five.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: So many morrowes,
Those five remaining yeares ile turne to daies
To houres or minutes for thy company,
Tis fit that you and I being man and wife
Should walke together arme in arme.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I hope they'l goe together, I would they would i faith,
Then would her thirds be sav'd to, the day goes away sir.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Why wouldst thou have me gone Simonides?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O my hart, would you have me gone before you sir?
You give mee such a de●dly wound.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: fine rascall.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Blemish my duty so with such a qu●stion,
Sir I would hast me to the Duke fo● mercie,
He thats above the Law may mitigate
The rigor of the Law● how a good meaning
May be corrupted by misconstruction?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Thou cor●upt'st mine, I did not thinke thou meanest so.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You were in the more error.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: The words wounded me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Twas pittie thou diedst not ont.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: I have beene ransaking the helps of Law
Conferring with these learned advocates,
If any scruple cause or wrested sence
Could have been found out to preserve your life,
It had beene bought though with your full estate,
Your lifes so pretious to me, but there is none.

sp.speaker: 1. Law.
sp.l: Sir we have c●nva●'d it ●rom top to toe,
Turnd it upside downe, thr●w her on her side
Nay opend and dissected all her in●●oyles
Y●t can finde none, theres nothing to be hopd
But t●e Dukes mercie.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: I know the hope of that,
He did not make the Law for that purpose.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Then to his hopelesse mercy la●t I goe,
I have so many presidents b●fore me.
I must c●ll it hopelesse Antigona,
See me d●liverd up unto my deaths man
And then weell p●●t five years hence ile looke for thee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I hope sheel not stay so long behind you.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Do not bate him an houre by griefe and sor●ow
Since theres a day prefixed, haste it not,
Suppose me sick Antigona, dying now
Any Disease thou 〈◊〉 may be my end

Or when D●ath● slow to come, say Tyrants send
Exeunt●

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Cleanthes if you want money, to morrow use me,
Ile trust you while your fathers dead. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Why heres a villaine,
Able to corrupt a thousand by example,
Do●s the kind root bleede out his livelihood
In parent distribution to his branches,
Adorning 〈◊〉 with ●ll his glorious fruits,
Proud that his pride is s●●n when hees unseen,
And must not gratitude dis●end agen
To comfort his old limbs in fruitlesse winter
Improvident, at le●st partiall n●ture
Weak woman in this kinde, who in thy last
Te●ming still forgets ●he former, ever m●king
The burthen of thy last throws the dear●st
D●rling; oh yet in noble man reform it,
And make us better then those v●get ves,
Whose soules die within 〈◊〉; nature as thou art old,
If love and justice be not dead in thee,
Make some the patern of thy piety,
Lest all doe turn unn●turally against thee,

And thou be blam'd for our oblivions
Enter Leonides and Hippolit●.
And bru●sh ●eluctations; I● heers the ground
Whereon my filiall faculti●s mu●● build
A● edifice of honour or of ●hame
To all mankind.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You must avoid it sir:
If there be any love within your selfe,
This is far more then fate of a ●ost game
That another venture may r●store ●gen;
It is your life which you should not subj●ct
To any cruelty if you can preserve it.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O dearest woman, thou hast now doubled
A thousand times thy nuptiall dowry to me;
Why she whose love is but deriv'd from me
Is go● before me in my d●bted ●uty.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Are you thinking such a resolution sir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sweetest Hippolita what love taught ●hee
To be so forward in so good a cause?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Mine own pity sir, did first inst●uct me
And then your love and power did both command me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: They were all blessed angels to direct thee,
And take their counsell; how doe you fare sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Never better Cleanthes, I have conceiv'd
Such a new joy within this old bosome,
As I did never think would there have entred.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Joy call you it, alas tis sorrow sir,
The worst of sorrows, sorrow unto death.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Death, whats that Cleanthes, I thought not ont?
I was in contemplation of this woman.
Tis all thy comfort son, thou hast in her
A treasure unvaluable, keep her safe;
When I die, sure twilbe a gentle death;
For I will die with wonder of her vertues,
Nothing else shall disso●ve me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: 'Twere much better sir,
Could you prevent their malice.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Ile prevent ●m,
And die the way I told thee, in the wonder
Of this good woman. I tell thee there few men
Have such a child (I must thank thee for her)
That the stronger tie of wedlock should doe more
Then nature in her neerest ligaments
Of blood and prop●gation, I should neer
Have begot such a daughter of my own:
A daughter in law, law were above n●ture
Were there more such children.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: This admiration
Helps nothing to yeur safety, think of that sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Had you heard her Cleanthes but l●bour
In the search of means to save my forfe● life,
And knew the wise and sound preservation●
Th●t she fou●d out, you would redouble all
My wonder in your love to her.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The thought,
The very thought claims all that from m●,
And shees now possest of it, but good sir,
If you have ought r●ceiv'd from her advice,
Lets follow it, or else lets better thi●k,
And take the surest course.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Ile tell thee one,
She counsels me to flie my severe Country,
Turn all into treasure, and there build up
My decaying fortunes in a safer soyle,
Where Epires law cannot claim 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And sir, I apprehend it as safest course
And may be easily accomplished;
Let us be all most expeditious
Every Country where we breath will be our own,
O● better soile; heaven is the roof of ●ll,
And now as Epires situ●te by this law,
There is twixt us and heaven a dark eclipse.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Oh then avoid it sir, these s●d events
Follow those black predictions.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I prithee peace,
I doe allow thy love Hippolita,
But m●st not follow it as counsell, child;
I must not shame my Country for the law:
Th●s Country heer hath bred me, brought me up,
And shall I now refuse a grave in her?
I'●e in my second infancy● and children
Nere sleep so sweetly in their nurses c●adle.
As in their naturall mothers.

sp.speaker: Hip,
sp.l: I but sir,
She is unnaturall, then the stepmother
Is to be preferd before her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Tush, she shall
Allow it me dispite of her intrailes;
W●y doe you think how far from judgement tis
That I should travell forth to seek a grave
That is already digd for me at home,
Nay perhaps find it in my way to seek it?
How have I then sought a repentant sorrow?
For your dear loves how have I banishd you
From your Country ever with my base attempt
How have I beggerd you in wasting that
Which only for you● sakes I b●●d together,
Buried my name in Epire which I built
Upon this frame to live for ever in.
What a base coward shall I be to flie
From that enemy which every minute meets me?
And thousand odds he had not long vanquishd me
Before this howr of battell, sly my death
I will not be so false unto your stat●s,
Nor fainting to the man thats yet in me,
Ile meet him b●avely, I cannot (this knowing) fear
That when I am gone hence I shalbe there,
Come, I have d●yes of preparation left.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Good sir, hear me●
I have a Genius that has prompted me,
And I have almost formed it into words,
Tis done, pray you observe em, I can conceale you
And yet not leave your Country.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Tush, it cannot be
With●ut a certain perill ons all.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: D●nger must be hazarded rather then accept
A sure destruction● you have a Lodge sir,
So far remote from way of passengers,
Th●t seldo●e any mortall eye does greet with it,
And yes so sweetly situate with thickets
Built with such cunning L●borinths within,
As if the provident heavens foreseeing cruelty
Had bid you frame it to this purpose only.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Fie, fie, tis dangerous, and treason to,
To abuse the law,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Tis holy care sir,
Of your dear life, which is your own to keep,
But not your own to lose, either in will
O● negligence.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Call you it treason sir,
I had been then a traitor unto you,
Had I forgot this, beseech you accept of it,
It is secu●e●●nd a duty to your selfe.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What a co●●rd will you make me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You mist●ke●
Tis noble courage, now you fight with death,
And yeeld not to him till you stoop under him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: This must needs open to d●scovery,
And then what tortor followes?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: By what means sir?
Why theres but one body in all this ●ounsell,
Which cannot betray it selfe, we two are one,
One soule, one body, one heart, that think all one though●,
And yet we two are not compleatly one,
But as have deriv'd my selfe from you,
Who shall betray us where there is no second?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You must not mistrust my faith though my sex●
Plead weak and frailty for me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Oh I dare not!
But wheres the means that must make answer for me
I cannot be lost without a full accompt,
And what must pay that reckoning?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Oh sir, we will
Keep solemn obits for your funerall;
Weell seem to weep, and seem to joy withall
That death so gently has prevented you
The L●wes sharp rigor, and this no mortall ear
Shall participate the knowledge of.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,
This wilbe a sportive fine Demur●
If the Error be not found.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Pray doubt of none
Your company and best prouision
Must be no further furnisht then by us,
And in the interim your solitude
M●y converse with heaven, and fairly prepare
Which was too violent and raging
Th●own headlong on you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Still there are some doubts
Of the discovery, yet I doe allow't.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Will you not mention now the cost and charge
Which wilbe in your keeping?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That wilbe somewhat
Which you might save to.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: With his will against him;
What foe is more to man then m●n hims●lf●?
Are you resolv'd sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I am Cleanth●s:
If by this means I doe get a repriev●
And cozen de●th a while, when he shall come
Arm'd in his own power to give the blow,
Ile smile upon him ●hen, and laughing goe. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. II. Scen. I.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: EXecutioner.

sp.speaker: Exe.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How did old Diocles take his death?

sp.speaker: Exe.
sp.l: As weeping Brides receive their joyes at night my Lord,
With trembling yet with patience.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why twas well.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Nay I knew my Father would d●e well my Lord.
When ere ●e came to die, i'de that opinion of him.
Which made me the more willing to part from him;
He was not fit to live ●'th world indeede any time these
Ten yeares my Lord.
But I would not say so much.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No, you did not well in●,
For he thats all spent is ripe for death at all houers,
And does but trifle time out,

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Troath my Lord,
I would I had knowne your minde nine yeares agoe,

sp.speaker: Duke,
sp.l: O●r Law is fourscore years, because we judge
Do●age compleat then, as unfruitfullnesse
In Women at threescore, marrie if the son
Can within compasse bring good sollid proofes
Of his own fath●rs weaknes and unfitnes
To live or sway the living though he want five
Or ten yeares of his number, thats not it,
His defect makes him fourscore, and tis fit
He dies when he deserves, for every ●ct
Is in ●ff●ct then when the cause is ripe.

sp.speaker: 2. Court.
sp.l: An admirable Prince how rarely he talks?
Oh that w'eed knowne th●s Ladds, what a time did we endure
In two penny Com●ons? and in bootes twice vamp'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Now we h●ve ●wo p●ire a weeke, & yet not thankfull,
Twill be a fine world for them sirs that come after as.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.p: I and they knewt. 2. Cou. Pe●ce let them never knowt.

sp.speaker: 3. Cour.
sp.p: A Pox the●e be yong heires will soone smelt out.

sp.speaker: 2. Court.
sp.l: Twill come to em by instinct man, may your grace
N●v●r be old, you stand so well for youth.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why now me thinks our Court lookes like a Spring,
Sweet, fresh, and fashionable, now ●he old weeds are gon.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.p: Tis as a Court should be: Glosse and good Clothes,
My Lord no matter for merit and herein your Law p●ooves a provid●nt act my Lord, when men passe not the palsie of their Tongues, no● co●our in their Cheeks.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But women by that Law should live long,
For th'are ne●r past it.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: It will have heates though when they see the painting
Goe an inch deep ith wrincle, and take up
A box more then their Gossips, but for men my Lord
That should be the sole bravery of a Pallace,
To walke with hollow eyes and long white beards,
(As if a P●irce dwelt in a Land of Goates)
With Clo●hes as if they sat upon their backs on purpose
To arraigne a fashion and condemn't to exile
Their pockets in their sleeves, as if they layd
Their eare to avarice, and heard the Divell whisper;
Now ours lie downward heere close to the flanck,
Right spending pockets as a sonnes should be
T●at lives i●h fashion, where our diseased fathers
Would with the Sciatica and Aches
B●ought up y●ur p●ind hose first, which Ladies laught at,
Giving no reverence to the place, (lies ●uind,)
They love a doublet thats three houres a buttoning,
And sits so close makes a man groane agen,
And his Soule m●tter halfe a day; yet these are those
That carry sway and worth, prickd up in Clothes,
Why should we feare our rising?
You but wrong
Our kindnesse, and your owne deserts to doubt ont,
Has no● our Law made you rich before your time?
Our countenance then c●n make you honourable.

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: Weel spare for no cost sir to appeare worthy.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Why y'are i'th noble way then, for the most
Are but appearers, worth it selfe it is lost

And bravery st●nds fort.
Enter Creon, Anti|gona & Simonides.

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: Look, look, who comes heere
I smell Death ●nd another Courtier,
Simonides.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: Sim.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Push, I'me not for you yet,
You● companies too costly, ●fter the old mans
D●spatch'd I shall have time to talke with you,
I ●hall come into the fashion yee shall see too
After a day or two, in the meane time
I am not for your company.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Old Cr●on you have been expected long.
Sure y'are above fourscore.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Upon my life
Not four and twenty houres my Lord, I search'd
The Chu●ch Booke yesterdaie, does your Grace think
I'de let my Father wrong the Law my Lord?
Twere pitty a'my life then, no your Act
Shall not receive a minutes wrong by him
While I live sir, and hee's so just himselfe too
I know he would no offer't, heere he stands.

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: Tis just I die indeed my Lord, for I confesse
I'me troublesome to life now, and the State
Can hope for nothing worthy from me now,
Either in force or counsell, I've alate
Employd my selfe quite from the World, and he that once
Begins to serve his maker faithfully
Can never serve a worldly Prince well after,
Tis cleane another way.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: Oh give not confidence
To all he speaks my Lord in his own injury!
His preparation only for the next world
Makes him talk wildly to his wrong of this,
He is not lo●t in judgement.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She spo●ls all agen.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: Des●rving ●ny way for st●te imploiment.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Mother.

sp.speaker: Anti
sp.l: His v●ry houshold laws presc●ib'd at home by him
A●e able to confo●m 7. Christian kingdomes,
Th●y are so wise and vertu●us.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Mother, I say.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: I know your lawes extend not to desert sir,
But to unn●cessary years, and my Lord
His are no● such, though th●y shew white, they'r worthy,
Jud●t●●us, able, and religious.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Ile help you to a Courtier of nineteen, Moth●r.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: Awa● unnaturall.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Then I am no fool I'me sure,
Fo● t● be naturall at such a time
W●re a fool ●s part ind●ed.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: You● G●aces pity sir,
An t●s but fit and just.

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: ●h● law m● Lord,
And thats the j●st●st way.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: W●●l said ●ather ●faith.
Thou wert ever juster then my mother still.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Come hither sir.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: What are those orders?

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: Worth obse●vation sir,
So please you hear them read.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: The woman speaks she knows not what my Lord:
He make a L●w, poor man he bought a Table indeed,
Only to learn to d●e by't; ther's ●he busines now
W●erein there ●re some precepts for a son to,
How he should l●arn to live, but I neer lookt upont:
For when hees dead I shall live well enough,
And keep a better Table then ●hat I trow●

sp.speaker: Du
sp.l: And is that a●l sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: All I vow my Lord,
Save a few ●unning admonitions
Upon Cheese Trenchers, as Take heed of whoring, shun it;
Tis like a cheese too strong of the Runn●t,
And such calves maws of wit and admonition
Good to catch mice with, but not sons and heirs,
They'r not so easily caught.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Agent for death.

sp.speaker: Exe.
sp.l: Your will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Take hence that pile of years
Before surfet with unprofitable age
And with the rest from the high promontory,
Cast him into the sea.

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: Tis noble justice.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: Tis cursed tyranny.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Peace, take heed mother, you have but a short time to bee cast down your selfe, and let a yong Courtier doo't, and you bee wise, in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Anti
sp.l: Hence sl●ve.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Well seven and fif●y,
Yave but three years to sco'd, then comes your payment,

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: Simonides.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Push, I am not b●ave enough to hold you talk yet,
Give a m●n time. I have a su●t a m●king. Recorders.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: We love thy form fi●st, brave cloths will come man.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Ile make em come else with a mischief to em●
As other gallants doe, that have lesse left em.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Hark whence those sounds, whats that?

sp.speaker: 1. Cou.
sp.l:
Some funerall
Recorders. Enter Cleanthes & Hi|polita with a hears
It seems my Lord, and yong Cleanthes follows.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Cleanthes.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: Tis my Lord, and i● the place
Of a chi●fe mourner to, but strangely habited.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Yet su●table to his b●haviour, mark it,
He comes all the way smiling, do you observ't?
I ●ever saw ● Co●rse so joyfully followe●,
L●ght co●ou●s and light cheeks, who should this be?
Tis ● thi●g worth resolving.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: One belike that doth participate
In this our present joy.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Cleanthes,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Oh my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He laught outright now,
Was ever such a contrariety seen
In naturall courses yet, nay profest openly?

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: I ha known a widow laugh closely my Lord
Under her handkercher, when tother part of her old face has w●●
Lik● rain in sunshine, but all the face to laugh apparantly
Was never seen yet.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yes mine did once.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Tis of a heavy time the joyfullst day
That ever son was born to.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How can that be●
I joy to make it plain, my father's dead.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: Old L●onides.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: In his last month dead,
He beguil'd cruell L●w the sweetliest
Tha● ever age was blest to,
It g●ieves me that a tear should fall upont,
Being a thing so joyfull; but his memory
Will work it out I see; when his poor heart b●oke
I did not so much but leapt for joy,
So mountingly I touchd the stars me thought,
I would not hear of blacks I was so light●
But chose a colour Orient, like my mind,
For bla●ks are often such dissembling mourners,
There is no credit given toot, it has lost
All reput●tion by false sons and widows;
Now I would have m●n know what I resemble,
A truth indeed, tis joy clad like a joy,
Which is more honest then a cunning griefe
Th●t's only fac'd with s●bles for a shew,
But gawdy hearted; when I saw death come
So ready to deceive you, sir forgive me,
I could not choose but be intirely merry,
And yet to see now of a sudden
Naming but Death, I shew my selfe a mortall,
Thats never constant to one passion long;
I wonder whence that tear came when I smild,
In the production on't, sorrows a thiefe,
That can when joy looks on steal forth a griefe,
But gracious leave my Lord, when I have performd
My last poor duty to my fathers bon●s,
I shall return your servant.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Well perform it,
The Law is satisfied, they can but die,
And by his death Cleanthes you gain well,
A rich and faire revenew. Florish

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I would I had een another father, condition he did the like

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I have past it bravely, now how blest was I
To have the dim sight, now tis confirmd
Past fear or doubts confirmd, on on I say,
He that brought me to man I bring to clay.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'me wrapt now in a contemplation,
Even at the very sight of yonder Hearse,
I doe but think what a fine thing tis now
To live and follow some seven unkles thus,
As many Cozen Germans, and such people
That will leave Legacies, a pox Ide see em hangd else ere Ide follow
One of them, and they could finde the way now Ive enough to be|gin to be horrible covetous.

div.stage: Enter Butler, Tailor, Bayly, Cook, Coachman, and Footman.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: We come to know your Worships pleasure sir,
Having long serv'd your father, how your good will
Stands towards our entertainment.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Not a jot i faith:
sp.p: My father wore cheap garments, he might doot, I shall have all my Clothes come home to morrow, they will eat up all you, and there were more of you sirs; to keepe you sixe at Livery and still mun|ching.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Why I'me a Taylor, y'ave most need of me sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Thou mad●st my fathers clothes that I confesse,
But what sonne and heir will have his fathers Taylor
Unlesse he have a mind to be well laught at? Thast beene so us'd to wide long side things, that when I come to trusse I shall have the waste of my Dublet lie upon my buttocks, a sweet sight.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I a Butler.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Theres Jeast neede of thee fellow, I shall nere drinke at Home, I shall be so drunke abroad.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: But a cup of small beere will do well next morning sir

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I grant you, but what neede I keepe so big a knave for a Cup of sm●ll Beere?

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.l: Butler you have your answer, marry sir a Cooke,
I know your mastership cannot be without.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The more asse art thou to think so, for what should I doe With a Mountebancke, no drinke in my house, the banishing the Butler might have beene a warning for thee, unlesse thou meanst to Choake me.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.l: Ith meane time you have choaked me, me thinks.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.l: These are superfluous vanities indeed,
And so accounted of in these dayes sir,
But then your B●yliff to receive your rents.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I prithee hold thy tongue fellow, I shall take a course to sp●nd em faster then thou canst reckon em, tis not the rents must se●ve my turne, unlesse I meane to be laughed at, if a man should be seene out of slash me, let him nere look to be a right gallant: But ●irrah with whom is y●ur businesse?

sp.speaker: Coach
sp.l: Your good mastership.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You have stood silent all this while, like men
That know their strengths i'these dayes, none of you
Can want imployment, you can winne me wagers
Footman in running races.

sp.speaker: Foot
sp.l: I dare boast it sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And when my bets are all come in and store
Then Coachman you can hurry me to my whore.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.l: Ile ●i●ke em into foame else.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Speaks brave matter,
And ile firk some to, or't shall cost hot water.

sp.speaker: Cooke
sp.p: Why heares an age to make a Cooke a Ruffin, and scald the D●vell indeed, doe strange mad things, make mutton pasties of Dogs flesh, backe Snal●es for Lamprie Pies, and Cats for Cunnies:

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Come will you bee ruld by a Butlers advice once? for wee must m●ke up our fortunes some where now as the case stands, le●s ●en therefo●e goe seeke out widdowes of nine and fiftie and we can, thats within a yeare of their deaths, and so we shall bee sure to bee quickly ridd of em, for ● yeares enough of conscience to bee
troubled with a wife for any man living.

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: Oracle Butler, Oracle Butler, hee puts downe all the Doctors a'th name. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Parthenia.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Mother.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I shall be troubled
This six months with an old Clogg, would the Law
Had been cut one yeare shorter.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Did you call forsooth.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Yes, you m●st make some spoone meat for your father,
And warme three night capps for him, out apont
The meer conceit turns a yong womans stomack,
His slippers must be warmd in August too,
And his gowne girt to him in the very dogdaies
When every Mastiffe lo●s ou●s tongue for heat,
Would not this vex a beauty of 19. now?
Alas I shall be tumbling in cold Bathes now
Under each arme pit a fi●e beane flower bag
To screw out whitenesse when I list,
And some seaven of the proprest men ith Dukedome,
M●king a B●nquet ready ith next roome for me,
Where he that gets the first kisse is envied
And stands upon his guard a fortnight after;
This is a life for nineteene, but tis ju●●ice
For old men, whose great acts stand in their minds
And nothing in their bodies, doe nere think
A woman yong enough for their desire,
And we yong wenches that have mother wits
A●d love to marry muck first, and man after,
Doe n●ver ●hinke old men are old enough
That we may soon be rid on em theres ou● quittance;
I have wasted for the happy houre this two yeare
And if D●a●h be so unkind st●ll to let him live

All that time I am lost.
Enter Courtiers.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Yong Lady.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: O ●weet p●●cious bu● of beauty!
Troth she smells over all the house me thinks.

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: The Sweet Briers but a counterfeit to her●
It does exceede you only in the prickle,
But that it shall not long if youl be rul'd Lady●

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What meanes this suddain visitation Gentlemen?
So passing well perform'd too, whose your Milliner?

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Love and thy Beauty Widdow.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Widdow sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: Tis sure and thats as good, in troath w'are suitors
We come a wooing wench, plain dealings best.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: A wooing, what before my Husbands dead?

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: Lets lose no time, 6. months will have an end you know,
I know't by all the Bonds that ere I made yet.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Thats a sure knowledge, but it holds not heere sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.p:
Do not you know the craft of your yong Tumblers? That you wed an old man, you thinke upon another husband as yo● are marrying of him, wee knowing your thoughts made bold to see you.
Enter Simonides, Coachman.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: How wondrous right he speaks 'twas my thought indeed.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: By your leave sweet Widdow, do you lack any gallants?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Widdow agen, tis a comfort to be cald so.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Whose this Simonides.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: Brave Sim I faith.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Coachman.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Have an especiall care of my new mares,
They say sweet Widdow he that loves a horse well
Must needs love a Widdow well, when dies thy Husband?
I'st not Iuly next.
Oh y'are to hot sir!
Pray coole your selfe and take September with you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: September oh I was but two Bowes wide.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Mr. Simonides.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l:
I can entreat you gallants, I'me in fashion too.
Ent. Lisander.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Ha, whence this heard of folly, what are you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Well willers to your wife, pray tend your booke sir,
We have nothing to say to you, you may goe die,
For heere be those in place that can supply.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Whats thy wild businesse heere?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Old man, i'le tell thee,
I come ●o beg the reversion of thy Wife,
I think these gallants be of my mind too, but thou art but ● dead
Man, therefore what should a man doe talking with thee,
Come Widdow stand to your t●ckling.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Impious blood hounds.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Let the Ghost talke, nere mind him.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Shames of nature.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Alass poore Ghost, consider what the man is.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Monsters unnaturall, you that have beene covetous
Of your own fathers deaths, gape yee for mine now?
Cannot a poore old man that now can reckon
Een all the houres he has to live, live quiet
For such wild beasts as these, that neither hold
A certainty of good within themselves,
But scatter others comforts that are ripened
For holy uses? is hot youth so hasty
It will not give an old man leave to die?
And leave a Widdow first, but will make one
The Husband looking on, may your destructions
Come all in hasty figures to your Soules,
Your wealth depart in hast, to overtake
Your honesties, that died when you were infants.
May your male seed be hasty spend thrifts too?
Your daughters hastie sinners and diseas'd
Ere they be thought at yeares to welcome misery,
And may you never know what leisure is
But at repentance: I am too uncharitable
Too foule, I must goe cleanse my selfe with prayers;
These are the Plagues of fondnesse to old men
Wee'r punisht home with what we doat upon. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: So so, the Ghost is vanish'd now, your answer Lady.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Exc●se me gentlemen, 'twere as much impudence
In me to give you a kind answer yet.
As madnesse to produce a churlish one.
I could say now, come a month hence sweet gentlemen,
Or two or three, or when you will indeed,
But I say no such thing. I set no time
Nor is it mannerly to deny any,
Ile car●y an even hand to all the world,
Let other women m●ke what hast they w●ll,
Whats that to me, but I profess unfainedly●
Ile have my husband dead before I marry,
Ner● looke for other answer at my hands Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Would he were hangd for my part looke for other.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Ime at a word

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And Ime at a blow then,
Ile lay you o'th lips and leave you.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Well struck Sim.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: He that dares say heell m●nd it, Ile strike him.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: He would betray himselfe to be a brother
That goes about to m●nd it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Gentlemen, you know my minde, I bar you not my house,
But if you choose out houres more seasonably
You may have entertainment.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What will she doe heerafter when sh is a widow,
Keeps open house already? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: How now Girle?

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: Those featherd fools that hither took their flight,
Have griev'd my father much.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Speak well of youth Wench
While th●●st a day to live; tis youth must make thee,
And when youth fails, wise women will make it;
But alwayes take age first to make thee rich:
That was my counsell ever, and then youth
Will make thee sport enough all thy life after.
Tis Times policy Wench● wh●t ist to bide
A little hardness for a pair of years or so,
A man whose only strength lies in his breath,
Weaknes in all parts else, thy bedfellow
A cough oth Lungs, or say a wheening matter,
Then shake off chains, and dance all thy life after.

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: Eve●y ●n● to their liking● but I say
An honest man's worth all, be he yong or gray,
Yonders my Coz●n.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: A●t I must use thee now,
Dissembling is the b●st help for a vertue
That ever woman had, it saves their credit often.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: How now Cozen,
What weeping?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Can you blame me when the time
Of my dear Love and Husband now drawes on;
I study funerall rears against the day
I must be a sad widow.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: In troth Eugenia I have cause to weep to,
But when I visit, I come comfortably,
And look to be so quited, yet more sobbing.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Oh the greatest part of your affliction's past,
The worst of mine's to come, I have one to die,
Your husbands father is dead, and fixt
In his eternall pe●ce, past the sharp tyrannous blow.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You must use patience Coze.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Tell me of patience.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You have example fort in me and many.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Yours was a father in law, but mine a husband●
On for a woman that could love and live
Wi●h an old man, mine is a jewell Cozen,
So quietly he lies by one, so still.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Alas! I have a secret lodg'd within me
Which now will out, in pity I can't hold.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: One that will not disturb me in my sleep
After a whole month together, lesse it be
With those diseases age is subject to,
As aches, coughes, and pains, and these heaven knows
Against his will too, hees the quietest man,
Especially in bed.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Be comforted.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: How can I Lady?
None knowes the terror of an husbands losse●
But they that feare to lose him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Fain would I keep it in, but twill not be,
She is my kinswoman, and i'me pitifull,
I must impart a good if I knowt once,
To them that stand in need ont, Ime like one
L●v●s not to banquet with a joy alone,
My friends must partake too, prithee cease Cozen
If your love be so boundless, which is rare
●n a yong woman in these dayes, I tell you,
To one so much past service as your husband,
There is a way to beguile law, and help you,
My husband ●ound it out first.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Oh sweet Cozen!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You may conceale him, and give out his death
Within the time, order his funerall too;
We had it so for ours, I prayse heaven fort,
And hees alive and safe.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: O blessed Coze,
How thou reviv'st me?

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.l: We daily see
The good old man, and fe●d him twice a day,
Me thinks it is the sweetest joy to cherish him,
That ever life yet shewd me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: So should I think
A dainty thing to nurse an old man well.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And then we have his prayers and daily blessing.
And we two live so lovingly upont,
His son and I, and so contentedly,
You cannot think unlesse you tasted ont.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: No I warrant you, Oh loving Cozen,
What a great sorrow hast thou eas'd me of?
A thousand thanks goe with thee.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I have a suite to you, I must not have you weepe when I am gone. Exit.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: No, if I doe neer trust me: Easie fool,
Thou hast put thy selfe into my power for ever:
Take heed of angring of me; I conceal,
I fain a Funerall, I keep my husband,
Lasse I have been thinking any time these two years
I have kept him too long already.
Ile goe count ore my Suitors, thats my business,
And prick the man down, I ha six months to doot,
But could d●spatch him in one, were I p●t toot. Exit.

div.head: Act. III. Scen. I.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: YOu have searcht o●e the Parish Chronicle● sir?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Yes sir, I have found out the true age and date of the party you wot on.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Pray you be covered sir.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: When you have shewd me the way sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Oh sir remember your selfe, you are a Clark.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: A small Clark sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Likely to be the wiser man si●, for your greatest Clarks are not alwayes so, as tis reported.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You are a great man in the Parish sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I understand my self so much the better ●ir, for all the best in the Parish pay duties to the Clark, and I would ow you none sir.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Since youl have it so, i'le be the first to hide my head.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Mine is a capcass now to our busines in your hand, good luck I hope, I long to be resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Look you sir, this is that cannot deceive you.
This is the Diall that goes ever true;
You may say Ipse dixit upon this witnes,
And tis good in Law too.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Pray you lets bear what it speaks.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Mark sir, Agatha the daughter of ●ollux, this is your Wives name, and the name of her father, born.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Whose daughter s●y you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The daughter of Poll●x

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I take it his name was Bollux.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Pollux the Orthography I assure you sir, the word is cor|●upted els●.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Well on sir of Pollux, now come on ●●stor.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Born in an. 1540. and now tis 99. by 〈◊〉 i●●●llib●e record sir (let me see) she is now just 59. and 〈◊〉 but on.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am sorry 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why sir? alas tis nothing, tis but so many months, so ma|ny weeks, so many—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Do not deduct it to dayes● twill be the more tediou●, and to measure it by houre glasses were intollerable.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Doe not think on it sir, halfe the time goes away in sleep, tis halfe the yeare in nights.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oh you mistake me neighbour, I am loath to leave the good old woman. if shee were gone now it would not grieve mee, for what is a yeare alasse but a lingring torment? and were it not bet|ter she were out of her paine, t●must needs bee a griefe to us both.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I would I knew how to ease you neighbour?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: You speake kindly truly, and if you say but Amen to it, (which is a word that I know you are perfect in) it might be don, Cla●ks are the most ind●fferent honest men, for to the marriage of your enemy, or the buriall of your friend, the Curses or the Bles|sings ●o you are all one, you say Amen to all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: With a better will to the one then the other neighbour, but I shall be glad to say Amen to any thing might doe you a plea|sure.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: There is first somthing above your duty, now I would have you set forward the Clock a little, in to helpe the old woman out of her paine.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I will speake to the Sexton for that, but the day will go nere the faster for that.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oh neighbour you d●e not conceit mee, not the Jack of the Clock-house the hand of the Diall I meane, come, I know you be|ing a great Clark, cannot chuse but have the art to cast a figure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Never indeed neighbour, I never had the judgement to c●st a figure.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I'le show you on the back side of your booke, looke you, what figures this.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Four with a Cipher thats forty.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: So forty, whats this now?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: The Cipher is turn'd into 9. by adding the taile which m●k●s forty nine.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Very well understood, what i'st now?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: The 4. is turnd into 3. tis now thirty nine.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Very well understood, and can you do this agen?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh easily sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A wager of that, let me see the place of my wives age agen.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Looke you sir tis heere 1540.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Forty drachmaes, you do● not turne that forty into thirty nine.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A match with you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Done, and you shall keepe stakes your selfe there they are.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A firme match, but stay sir now I consider it, I shall add a yeare to your wives age, let mee see Scirophon the 17. and now tis H●catomcaon the 11. if I alter this your wife will have but a month to live by the Law.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Thats all one sir, either doe it or pay me my wager.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Will you lose your wife before you lose your wager?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A man may get two wives before halfe so much money by em, will you doot?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I hope you will conceale me for tis flat corruption.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Nay sir I would have you keepe counsell, for I lose my money by't and should be laught at for my labour, if it should bee known.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Well sir, there tis done, is perfect 39. as can be f●und in black and white but mum sir, thers danger in this figure casting.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I sir, I know that better men then you have beene throwne over the barr for as little, the best is, you can be but throwne out of the Belfrie.

div.stage: Enter the Cook, the Taylor, Bayliffe, and Butler.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Lock close heere comes company, Asses have eares as well as Pitchers.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Oh Gnoth●s, how i'st? heer's a tri●k of discarded Cards of us, wee were ranked with Coats as long as our old master li|ved.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: And is this then the end of Serving men?

sp.speaker: Cooke.
sp.p: Yes faith, this is the end of serving men, a wise man were better serve one God then all the men in the world.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Twas wel! spak of a Cook, and are all faln into fasting daies and ember we●ks, that Cooks are out of use?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: And all Taylors will bee cut into L●sts and Shreds, if this world hold, we shall grow both out of requ●st.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And why not Butler● aswell as Taylors, if they can goe naked, let em neither eat nor drink.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Thats strange mee thinks, a Lord should turne away h●s
Taylor of all men, and how dost thou Taylor?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I do so so, but indeed all our wants are long of this Pub|lican my Lords Bayliff, ●or had he been rent gatherer still, our pla|ces had held together still, that are now seame rent, nay crack'd in the whole peece.
Sir, if my Lord had not sold his Lands that claime hi● Rents, I should still have beene the rent gatherer.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: The truth is, except the Co●thman, and the Footman, all ●erving men are out of requ●st.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Nay say not so, for you were never in more request then now; for requ●sting is but a kind of a begging, for when you say I b●seech your Worships Charity, tis all one if you say I requ●st i●● and in that kind of r●questing, I am sure serving men were ne|ver in more req●est.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Troath hee sayes true, well let that passe, wee are upon a better a●venture. I see Gnothos you have beene before us, we came to deale with this Merchant for some commodities.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: With me sir any thing that I can.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Nay we have look'd out our Wives already, marry to you we come to know the prices, that is to know their ages for so much reverence we beare to age, that the more aged, they shall be the more deere to us.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: The tru●h is every man has laid by his Widdow, so they be lame enough, blinde enough, and old, tis good enough.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I ke●pe the town stock, if you can but name em, I can tell their ages today.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: We can tell their fortunes to an houre then.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Only you must pay for turning of the leaves.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Oh bountifully, come mine first!

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: The Butler before the Cooke while you live, thers few tha● eate before they drinke in a morning.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Nay then the Taylor puts in his needle of priority, for m●n do cloth themselves before they either drink or eat.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: I will strive for no place, the lo●ger ere I ma●ry my wife, the older shee will be, and nearer her end and my ends.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I will serve you all gentlemen if you will h●ve patience.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I commend your modesty sir, you are a Bayliff whose place is to come behind other men, as it were in the bumm of all the rest.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p:
So sir, and you were about this businesse too, seeking out
for a Widdow.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Alack no sir, I am a married man, and have those cares up|on me that you would faine runn into.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: What an old rich wife, any man in this age desires such a care.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Troath sir I'le put a venter with you if you will, I have a lusty old qu●ane to my wife, sound of wind and limb, yet I'le give out to take three for one● at the marriage of my second wife.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: I sir, but how neere is shee to the Law?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Take that at hazard sir, there must bee time you know to get a new: Unsigh●, unseen, I take 3. to one.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: Two to one I'le give if shee have but two teeth in her head.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A ma●ch, theres five drachmes for ten at my next wife.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I shall be fitted bravely, fifty eight and upwards, tis but a yeare and a halfe, and I may chance make friends, and beg a yeare of the Duke.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Hey boyes I am made sir Butler, my wife that shall bee wants but two months of her time, it shall bee one ere I marry her, and then ●h● next will be a hunny moon.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I out st●ip you all, I shall have but six weeks of Lent, if I get my Widdow, and then comes eating tide plump and gorgious.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: This Taylor will be a man if ever there were any.

Now comes my turn, I hope goodman Finis, you that are still at the end of all with a so be it, well now sirs, doe you venter there as I have done? and ile venter heereafter you, good luck I be|seech thee.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Amen sir.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: That deserves a fee already, there tis, please me and have a better.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Amen sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: How two for one at your next wife, is the old one li|ving?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: You have a faire Match, I offer you no foule one, if Death make not hast to call her, shee'l make none to go to him.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I know her, shees a lusty woman, I'le take the venter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Theres five drachm●es for ten at my next wife.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: A bargain.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Nay then weel be all Merchants give me.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: And me.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: What has the Bayliff sped?

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: I am con●ent, but n●ne of you shall know my happiness.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: As well as any of you all believe it sir.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: Oh Clarke you are to speak last alwayes.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
I'le remember't h●reafter sir● you have done with mee Gentlemen?
Enter Wife.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: For this time honest Register.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Fare you well then, if you do, I'le cry Amen toot. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Looke you sir is not this your Wife?
My first wife sir.
Nay then we have made a good match ont, if she have no froward Disease, the Woman may live this dozen yeares by her age.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I'me afraid shees broken winded, shee holds silence so long.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: We●l now leave our venter to the ev●nt, I must a woo|ing.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Ile but buy me a new dagger, and overtake you.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: So we must all, for he that goes a wooing to a Widdow without a weapon will never get her. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oh Wife, Wife!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What ●yle you man you speake so passionatly.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Tis for thy sake sweet wife, who would thinke so lusty an old ●oman, with reasonable good teeth, and her tongue in as per|fect use as ever it was, should bee so neere her time, but the Fates will have it so?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Whats the matter man, you doe amaze me?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Thou art not sick neither I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Not that I know of sure.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: What pitty tis a woman should bee so neere her end, and yet not sick●

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Neere her end man, tush I can guesse at that,
I have yeares good yet of life in the remainder,
I want two yet at least of the full number,
Then the Law I know craves impotent and useless
And not the ●ble women.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I alas I see thou hast beene repairing time ●s well as thou
couldst, the old wrinckles are well fild up, but the Vermilion is seene too thick, too thick, and I read whats written in thy fore|head, it agrees with the Church Booke.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Have you sought my age man, and I preethee how is it?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I shall but discomfort thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Not at all man, when there's no remedy, I will go though unwillingly.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: 1539. Just it agrees with the Booke, you have about a yeare to prepare your selfe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Out al●s, I hope theres more then so, but doe you not thinke a repreeve might be gotten for halfe a score, and twere but five yeare, I wo●ld not care, an able woman (me thinks) ●ere to be pittied.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I to be pittied, but not help'd, no hope of that, for indeed women have so blemishd their own reputations now a dayes, that it is thought the L●w will meet them at fifty very shortly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Marry the H●avens forbid.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Theres so many of you that when you are old become Witches, some professe Physick, and kill good subjects faster then a bu●ning Feavour; and then Schoolemistresses of the sweet sinne, which commonly we call Bawds innumerable of that sort: for these and such causes tis thought they shall not live above fifty.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I man but this hurts not the good old women.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I faith you are so like one another, that a man cannot distinguish 'em now; were I an old woman I would desire to goe before my time, and ●ff●r my selfe willingly, 2. or 3. yeares before; oh those are brave women and worthy to bee commended of all men in the world that when their Husbands die they run to bee burnt to death with em, theres honor and credit, give mee halfe a dozen such wives.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I if her Husband were dead before, 'twere a reasonable re|qu●st, if you were dead I could be content to be so.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Fie, thats not likely, for thou hadst two husbands before me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Thou wouldst not have me die, would'st thou husband?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No I do not speake to that purpose, but I say what credit it were for mee and thee, if thou wouldst, then thou shouldst never bee suspected for a Witch, a Physitian, a Bawd, or any of those things, and then how daintily should I mourne for thee, how brave|lie
should I see thee buried, when alas if hee goes before it cannot choose but bee a great griefe to him to thinke hee has not seene his wife well buried, there be such vertuous women in the world, but too few, too few who desire to die 7. yeares before their time with all their hearts.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I have not the heart to be of that mind, but indeed Hus|band I think you would have me gone.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: No alas I speake but for your good and your credit, for when a woman may die quickly, why should shee goe to Law for her Death, al●●k I neede not wish thee gone, for thou hast but a short time to stay with me, you do not know how neare tis, it must out, you have but a month to live by the Law.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Out alas.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Nay scarce so much.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, my heart! Swouns.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I so, if thou wouldst go away quietly twere sweetly done, and like a kind wife, lie but a little longer and the bell shall towle for thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh my hart, but a month to live.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Alas why wouldst thou come back agen for a month, i'le throw her downe agen, oh woman tis not three weeks, I thinke a fortnigh● is the most.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay then I am gone allready. Swouns.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I would make hast to the Sexton now, but I'me afraid the towling of the Bell will wake her agen; if she be so wise as to goe now, she stirs agen, ther's two lives of the nine gone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh wouldst not thou helpe to recover mee husband?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Alas, I could not find in my heart to hold thee by thy nose, or box thy cheeks, it goes against my conscience.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I will not be thus frighted to my Death,
I'le search the Church Record a fortnight
Tis too little of conscience, I cannot be so neare,
Oh time if thou bee●t kind lend me but a yeare. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
What a spites this, that a man cannot perswade his wife to dye in any time with her good will, I have another bespoke al|ready, though a peece of old beefe will serve to breakfast, yet a man would be glad of a Chicken to supp●r; the Clarke I hope un|derstands no Hebrew, and cannot write backward ●hat hee hath writ forward already, and then I am well enough: tis but a month
at most, if that were gon My venter comes in with her two for one, Tis use enough a con●c●ēce for a brother if he had a consc●ēce.
E●it.

div.stage: Enter Eugenia as one Dore, Simonides, Courtiers at the other.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Gentlemen Courtiers.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: All your s●rvants vowd Lady.
Oh I shall kill my selfe with infinite laughter!
Will no body take my part?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: An't be a laughing businesse
Put it to me, ●●me one of the best in Europe.
My father died last 〈◊〉, I h●ve the most cause.
Y●u ha pickd ou● such a time sweet Gentlemen
To m●ke y●u● spleen a ba●q●et.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Oh the jest Lady!
I have a jaw stands ready fort, ●l'e gape,
Halfe way and m●et it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: My old Husband
Th●t cannot s●y his pra●ers out for Jealosie
And madn●sse, at your comming fi●st to woe me.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.p: Well s●yd.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: Go on.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: On, on.
Takes Counsell with the secrets of all art
To make himselfe youthfull ●gen.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: How you●hfull, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: A man of forty five he woul● faine seeme to be
O● scarce so much if he might have his will indeed.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I but his white haires theyl betray his hoarin●sse.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: Why there you ●re wide, hees not th● man you take him for,
N●y will y●u know h●● when you see him agen,
There will be five to one layd upon that.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: How?
Nay you did well to laugh faintly there,
I pro●ise you I think he●l out live me now,
And deceive Law and all.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: M●rry gowt fo●bid.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You little think he was at Fencing Schoole
At foure a Clock this Morning.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: How at Fenc●ng School●?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Else give no trust to woman.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: By this light
I doe not like him then, hees like to live
Longer then I, for he may kill me first now.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: His dancer now came in as I met you.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: His dancer too.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: They observe turnes and houres with him●
The great French rider will be heere at ten
With his Curvetting Horse.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: These notwithstanding.
His haire and wrincles will betray his age.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I'me sure his Head and B●ard as he has orderd it
Looks not p●st fif●y now heel bringt to forty
Withi● these four dayes for 9 times an hour at least
He takes ● Black Lead Combe and kembs it over●
Three q●arters of his Beard is under fifty,

Thers but a little tuft of fourscore left
Enter Lisander.
All of one side which will be black by Munday,
And to approve my truth ●●e where he coms?
Laugh softly gentlemen, and looke upon him.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now by this hand hees almost black ith mouth indeed.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: He should die shortly then.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Marry me thinks he dies too fast already,
For he was all white but a weeke agoe.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Oh this same cunny white takes an excellent black,
Too soone a mischiefe ont.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: He will beguild us all
If that little tuft Northward turne black too.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nay sir I wonder tis so long a turning.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: May be some Fairies child held forth at midnight
Has pist upon that side.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Is this the Beard?

sp.speaker: Lis
sp.l: Ah sirrah my yong boyes I shall be for you,
This little m●ngle tuft takes up more time
Then all the Beard beside, come you a wooing
And I alive and lusty? you shall find
An alteration, Jack boyes I have a Spirit yet,
And I could match my haire too't, theres the fault,
A●d c●n doe offices of youth yet lightly.
At least I will doe though it paine me a little
Shall not a man for a little foolish age
Enjoy his Wife to himselfe, must yong Court ti●s
Play tomboyes tricks with her, and he live, ha?
I have blood that will not beart, yet I confesse

I should be at my prayers, but wheres the Dancer there.
Ent. Dan

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Heere sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Come, come, come, one trick a day,
And I shall soone recover all agen.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Slight and you laugh too loud, we are all discoverd Gen|tlemen

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And I have a scurvy ginny laugh a mine own.
Will spoyle all i'me afraid.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Marry take heed sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Nay and I should bee hangd I can't leave it, pup. there tis.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: Peace oh peace!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Come I am ready sir.
I heare the Church Bookes lost where I was borne to,
And that shall set me back one and twenty years
There is no little comfort left in that,
And my three Court Codlings that looke parboyld,
As ●if they c●me from Cupids scalding house.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: He meanes me specially I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: What trick will your old Worship learn this morning sir?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Marry a trick if thou couldst teach a man
To keepe his Wife to himselfe, i'de faine learn that.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: Thats a hard trick for an old man specially
The Horse trick comes the nearest.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Thou sayst true, I faith
They must be horst indeed, else theres no keeping on em
And horse play at fourscore is not so ready.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: Look you heers your Worships horse trick sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Nay say not so,
Tis none of mine I fall down horse and man,
If I but off●r at it.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: My life for yours sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Saist thou me so.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: Well offerd by my Violl sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: A Pox of this horse trick, t'as playd the jade with me
And given me a wrinch ith back.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: Now heeres your i●turne, and your trick above ground.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: P●ithee no more, unlesse thou hast a mind
●o lay me underground, one of these tricks
●nough in a morning.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: For your G●lli●rd sir
●●u are comple●t enough, I and may ch●llenge
●●e proudest Coxcombe of em all, i'le stand too●.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Faith and I've other weapons for the rest too,
●●ve p●ep●rd for em, if ere I take
〈◊〉 Gregories heere agen.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Oh I shall burst, I can hold out no longer.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Hee spoyles all.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: The Divell and his grinners are you come.
Bring forth the weapons we shall find you play,
All feats of youth to Jack Boyes, feats of youth.
And these the w●pons, drinking, fencing, dancing,
Your owne roade waies you Glisterpipes, Ime old you say
Yes parlo●s old Kidds and you mark me well,
This Beard cannot get Children, yon lank ●u●● eggs,
Unlesse such Weezels come from Court to help us

We will get our owne bratts, you lecherous dogbolts
Enter wi●● Glasses.
W●l said down with 'em now we shall see your spirits
What dwindle you already?

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: I have no quallity.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Nor I, unlesse drinking may be reckned
For one.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Why Sim it sh●ll.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Come dare you chus● your weapon now.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: I dancing sir and you will be so h●sty.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: We're for you sir.

sp.speaker: ●. Cour.
sp.l: Fencing I.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Weel answer you to.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'me for drinking your wet weapon there.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: That wet one has cost m●ny a p●incox life
And I will send it through you with a powder.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Let come with a Pox● I care no● so't be drink.
I hope my gu●s will hold, and ●hat's ●een all
A Gentleman can looke for of such trillibubs.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: P●●y the first weap●n, come strike, strike I say

Yes, yes, you shall be first, Ile observe Court Rules
A Ga●●ard L●|mini●rd
Alwayes the worst goes foremost, so twill prove I hope
So sir, y'ave spit your poyson, now come I,
Now forty years ago backward and assist me
Fall from me halfe my age but for three minutes,
That I may feel no crick, I will put faire fort
Although I hazzard twenty Sciaticaes
So I have hit you.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Y'ave done well I faith sir,

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: If you confesse it well tis excellent
And I have hit you soundly, I am warme now,
The second weapon instantly.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: What so quick sir, will you not allow your selfe a breathing time?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Ive breath enough at all times, Lucifers Musk cod●
To give your perfumd worship 3. Vennies,
A sound old man puts his thrust better home
Then a spic'd yong man, there I.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: Then have at you fourscore.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You l●e twenty I hope, and you shall find it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'me glad I mist this weapon, I had an eye
Popd out ere this time, or my two butter teeth
Thrust down my throat instead of a flap draggon.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Theres two, peptwizle.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: Excellently touch'd sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: Had ever man such luck, speak your opinion gentlemen●

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Me thinks your lucks good that your eyes are in stil,
Mine would have drop'd out like a pigs halfe toasted.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: There wants a third and there tis agen.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: The Divel has steeld him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What a strong fiend is Jelousie?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Your disp●tchd beare whelp.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now comes my weapon in.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Heere toad stoole, heere.
Tis with you and I must play these 3. wet Vennies.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Vennis in Venice Glasses, let em come
Theyl bruise no flesh Ime sure, nor break no bones.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: Yet you may drink your eyes out sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I but th●ts nothing then they goe voluntarily, I doe not
Love to have em thrust out whether they will or ●●●

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Heeres your first weapon du●k● meat.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: How, a dutch what you call em.
St●●d of a German falchion, a shrewd weapon●
And of all things, hard to be taken downe,
Yet downe it must, I have a nose goes in toot
I shall drinke double I think.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: The sooner off Sim.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Ile pay you speedily — with a trick.
I learnt once amongst drunkards, heeres halfe pike.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Halfe pike comes well after Dutch what you c●ll em,
They'd never be a sunder by their good will.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Well puld of an old fellow.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Oh but your fellowes
Pull better at a rope.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: Theres a haire Sim.
In that Glasse.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Ant be as long as a halter downe it goe●
No haire shall crosse me.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I make you stinke worse then your Pol●cats doe.
●eeres long sword your last weapon.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: No more weapons.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Why how now Sim beare up, thou ●hamst us all else.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Light I shall shame you worse and I stay longer.
I ha got the Scotony in my head already●
The whimzy, you all turne round, do no● you dance gallants.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: Pish whats all this? why Sim look the last Venny

sp.speaker: Sim.
